instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2883: What is 820-2883? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: A1342 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2883</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an A1342 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2883</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power. I have green light, but no fan spin, and it only pulls 0.15A on bench PSU.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.382V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.59V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.310V
PP1V1R1V05_S5 = 1.0V
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_G3H</SIGNAL> = 19.9V (using 20V on PSU)
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V

I think L7560 is shorted (0.008 diode reading), but I'm not sure...

Can you help?

threads.title: A1342 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2883</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
MCP core has low resistance to ground as normal.

Check resistance to ground at L6995 (ohm scale); should be higher than 30K.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

BTW, why do you like to test 60W machines with 20V?
Do you still expect to find a machine where VD0R will be triggered and you'll waste time for nothing on it?

threads.title: A1342 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2883</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Well, I test all machines with 20V, because of lack of knowledge. I never know what the consumption of each machine is for sure, and I thought it was nothing very serious in macbooks.  I will be more careful .

L6995 has 50K ohm to ground, and I have a drop pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  when trigering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

It seams that the problem is the power button...

TKS

threads.title: A1342 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2883</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> doesn't drop when pressing power button from keyboard?

"Well, I test all machines with 20V, because of lack of knowledge. I never know what the consumption of each machine is for sure"
Each charger has the output voltage marked on it, depending on its power.
